US captures Venezuelan leader Maduro, Trump says
subhead: The US president said that the US military had launched a large-scale operation in Caracas and that President Nicolas Maduro and his wife had been flown out of the country. The US attorney general announced charges against them.

title: Questions linger two days after Swiss resort bar fire
Kyrylo Budanov, master spy and Zelensky's new right hand
Iran crackdown intensifies as Trump threatens to intervene
subhead: At least eight protesters have been killed, 119 arrested and 33 injured since the protest movement began on December 28, 2025, according to human rights organizations. Security forces have stepped up operations in the provinces of Fars, Lorestan, Isfahan and Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari.

title: In Khartoum, the faces of a martyred capital: 'War cannot kill ideas, nor love'
subhead: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (3/6). Le Monde's reporters traveled through the Sudanese capital, which for two years was the epicenter of the conflict. They met with residents, who recounted how they survived despite fear and violence.

title: At the Louvre, tension builds over creation of new 'Mona Lisa' gallery
subhead: The Louvre-Nouvelle Renaissance architecture competition aims to create a room for Leonardo da Vinci's iconic painting and a new entrance for the Paris museum, which has seen a surge in visitors. Five teams have been shortlisted, none of which are French.

title: They cook organic, distrust science and oppose vaccines: America's 'crunchy moms' shift toward Trump
subhead: In the 1960s, the 'crunchy mom' was typically an American hippie trying to stay connected to nature. Today, she claims total freedom over health decisions, sometimes flirting with conspiracy theories.

Early Christian fresco depicting Jesus as the Good Shepherd discovered in Turkey
subhead: One month after Pope Leo XIV's visit, Turkish authorities announced the discovery in Iznik, Anatolia, of a depiction of Christ in a well-preserved burial chamber.

title: Switzerland in shock after tragic bar fire: 'It was a war zone. Burned hair, faces and hands'
subhead: The upscale French-speaking Alpine resort of Crans-Montana is in mourning after a fire in a bar claimed the lives of around 40 people and left 115 others seriously injured. Heart-wrenching testimonies and unanswered questions are pouring in.

title: 'I did it for the money, but I wasn't proud': Parties that hire 'dwarves' for entertainment
subhead: Hiring women or men of short stature to 'spice up' parties has become increasingly common in Europe in recent years. These practices raise both moral and legal questions.
